content.text: The student places a circular load of mass \(M = 20 \text{g}\) on the metre ruler but in a position different from that shown in Fig. 1.1
Determine the distance \(d_0\) of the centre of the load from the zero end of the ruler, as shown in Fig. 1.2. Fig. 1.2 is **not** to scale
The student places the metre ruler on the pivot and changes the position of the load so that the centre of the load is at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark
He adjusts the position of the metre ruler on the pivot until the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced
Describe a technique for ensuring that the ruler is as near as possible to being balanced
The student determines the scale reading \(p\) on the ruler at the position of the pivot
He calculates the distance \(a\) between the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot and the distance \(b\) between the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot, using the equations
He repeats the procedure for values of \(M = 40 \text{g}, 60 \text{g}, 80 \text{g}\) and \(100 \text{g}\)
His results are shown in Table 1.1
For the value of \(M = 20 \text{g}\), calculate and record in Table 1.1 the value of \(\frac{b}{a}\)
Plot a graph of \(M / \mathrm{g}\) ( \(y\) -axis) against \(\frac{b}{a}\) ( \(x\) -axis)
Draw the best-fit line
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: The mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre ruler is numerically equal to \(G\)
Write down the value of \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) in this experiment. Include the unit

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: The determination of \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) by this method assumes that the centre of mass of the metre ruler is at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark
Suggest how you could use apparatus from Fig. 1.1 to test whether the centre of mass of the metre ruler is at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark. You may draw a diagram
A student finds that the centre of mass of her metre ruler is at the \(48.7 \text{cm}\) mark
Suggest how she changes the procedure in **(b)**(ii) to allow for this
A student determines the mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of a metre ruler by a balancing method
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1
On Fig. 2.1, complete the circuit to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across resistor U
**Circuit A**
The student measures the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across resistor U and the current \(I\) in the circuit
Read, and record in Table 2.1, the values of \(V\) and \(I\) shown on the meters in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of resistor U for each combination of resistors
Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
A student suggests that the values of \(R\) should be the same
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
Circuit B
Fig. 2.4
Circuit C
Fig. 2.5
The student connects two \(3\Omega\) resistors in parallel between P and Q as shown in Fig. 2.4 to form circuit B
The student connects three \(3\Omega\) resistors in parallel as shown in Fig. 2.5 to form circuit C
For each circuit, she measures the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across resistor U and the current \(I\) in the circuit. Her readings are shown in Table 2.1
Complete the circuit in Fig. 2.6 to show a variable resistor used for this purpose
Briefly explain **one** advantage of using a variable resistor to determine the resistance of resistor U rather than the procedure carried out in **(b)** and **(c)**
A student determines the resistance of resistor U using a variable resistor to control the current in the circuit
A student suggests that potential difference and current for resistor U are proportional
State how a graph of potential difference against current for resistor U can confirm this suggestion
A student investigates a circuit containing different combinations of resistors
She uses **circuit A**, shown in Fig. 2.1
**Circuit A** is not yet complete
On Fig. 3.1, draw a normal to **FG** at point **N**. Extend the normal below **FG**. Label the lower end of the normal with the letter **L**
The student draws line **AN**, as shown in Fig. 3.1
On Fig. 3.1, measure the acute angle \(\theta_{1}\) between the lines **AN** and **GN**. (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
The student places two mirrors, **FE** and **FG**, at an angle of \(100^{\circ}\) to each other, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Measure the distance \(d\) between pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
Suggest whether the two pins are a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Explain your answer
statement
explanation
The student places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line **AN**, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The student views the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) in mirror **FE**
She places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) all appear one behind the other
* Draw a line through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Extend the line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) above **FE**
* Label the upper end of this line with the letter **R**
* Label the lower end of the line with the letter **B**
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines **BR** and **CT**. (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
A student thinks that there is a relationship between angle \(\alpha\) and the values of angle \(\theta_{1}\) from (a)(ii) and angle \(\theta_{2}\) from (d)
State what your results suggest that relationship could be. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
The student repeats the procedure for an angle \(\theta_2 = 40^\circ\)
She places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\), \(\mathsf{P}_6\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) all appear one behind the other
* Draw a line through pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\). Extend the line until it crosses **BR**
* Label the upper end of this line with the letter **T**
* Label the lower end of the line with the letter **C**
Suggest two precautions to take in this type of experiment to ensure accurate results
Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results
A student investigates the reflection of light by two plane mirrors
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full-size in Fig. 3.1
ray-trace sheet
A student investigates the rate of cooling of hot water in a container which has a lid
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effect of lids of different thicknesses on the rate of cooling
The apparatus available includes:
a beaker
a supply of hot water
insulating material from which lids can be cut
In your plan, you should:
list any additional apparatus needed
explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the rate of cooling can be determined
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
